Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: A long, wooden pier. Morning has broken and the first rays of sunshine can be seen shimmering down. The sun has risen and the hustle and bustle of the city is audible to the north. The midday sun is high in the sky and waves of heat can be seen shimmering off the waves. The bright blue skies of the afternoon bathe every wave in sunlight. The sun has set and the pier is shadowed in the failing light. Evening has fallen and the pier is dim. There is a slight chill in the air. Midnight has enveloped the silent pier. A slight lightening of the sky bathes the pier in an eerie light as dawn approaches. Several bronze cleats are fastened to the west and east sides for the mooring of ships. The pier extends approximately fifty feet into the waves and is twelve feet wide. The decking of the pier is crafted of hardened wood planks and rests on many firmly planted pilings. To the northeast is Dock Street.
A wooden pier. The pier is well lit by bright sunlight. The pier is enfolded in the cloak of night. Several cleats are fixed tightly on the east and west sides. To the northeast is Dock Street.
To the northeast is Dock Street. In this direction, you can see:

A wooden punt, basically just a leaky, rotting platform of wooden boards lashed together with rope. A chain crosses the river Granvert, allowing the punt to be pulled from one side of the river to the other.
You wait while the punt is hauled across the river Granvert.
steps onto the punt, and is hauled across the river.

Several bronze cleats are fastened to the west and east sides for the mooring of ships. The cleats are designed with an open base for strength and beauty and well structured for anchoring, docking and general all-purpose use. Made of solid bronze, these cleats have a beautiful gleam. They are also well-protected from corrosion.
Several bronze cleats are fastened to the west and east sides for the mooring of ships.

The creosote decking of a pier is crafted of "salt" treated lumber to avoid shipworm or gribble infestation, which weakens the lumber by boring tunnels. It also protects the wood from rot and fungi. The pier rests on many round-sided pilings since they are best because they withstand the wave action better, thus lasting longer.
The creosote decking of a pier.
